Recent torque magnetometry measurements of the anisotropic susceptibility within the ab planes of YBa 2Cu 3O 6+ δ (YBCO) revealed that the in-plane anisotropy displays a significant increase with a distinct cusp at T *, consistent with the possible existence of a nematic phase transition
23 . However, in YBCO, the fourfold ( C 4) rotational symmetry is already broken due to the orthorhombic crystal structure with one-dimensional (1D) CuO chains, and thus no further rotational symmetry breaking is expected. Moreover, in bilayer YBCO, the coupling of the CuO 2 planes in the unit cell may further affect the symmetry breaking
16 . Therefore, the investigation of an underdoped single-layer system with tetragonal symmetry, such as hole-doped HgBa 2CuO 4+ δ (Hg1201), is essential to clarify whether a nematic phase transition is an intrinsic and universal property of the high- T c cuprates. Figure 1 displays the temperature-doping phase diagram of Hg1201. Similar to other hole-doped cuprates, the phase diagram contains CDW, superconducting and pseudogap regimes
6, 7, 17, 18, 24, 25 . Short-range CDW order along [100]/[010], with wave vector close to 0.28 r.l.u., forms a dome-shaped boundary inside the pseudogap regime
6, 7 . In zero magnetic field, CDW domains with typical size of a few nanometres appear.
